May 23 20:27:39 longtail1 chef-client[29168]: service[druid@compute] restarted
May 23 20:27:42 longtail1 druid-compute[29702]: [main] Start: started [true]
May 23 21:15:13 longtail1 druid-compute[29702]: [main] jetty-6.1.x
by relative I meant relative to the configured size of the compute node

it would be cool not to rely on GC, it bugs me once in a while - in combination with slow compute node restarts, it's troublesome.

Maybe force a GC after X segments dropped?

We've seen some issues with this problem where if a compute node is not
queried enough and there's a high number of new segments entering the
cluster, the size of deleted file handles can grow enough to be annoying.
We can definitely take a look at possible solutions.

On Fri, May 24, 2013 at 2:16 AM, Hagen Rother notifications@github.comwrote:

> combination with slow compute node restarts, it's troublesome.

> Maybe force a GC after X segments dropped?
>

> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/metamx/druid/issues/89#issuecomment-18394594
> .

We should look at using reflection to get at the unmap method and unmapping the object, that's the best solution at this point and we shouldn't see any problems as long as we make sure we never use the MappedByteBuffer again.

The original reasoning for the order of the operations is that we load everything first before starting Jetty and publishing our existence to ZK because we don't want the master to start assigning segments until we load all of our local stuff.

I can see two general solutions for this.  

1) On our machines, the majority of this time is actually spent updating zookeeper one znode at a time.  I'd like to adjust our ZK interactions for publishing segments to actually batch up segments so that there would be more than one segment per znode.  This would decrease the total round trip time when loading off of the local disk and hopefully speed things up.

2) We could add a configuration switch that tells it to not wait for all the segments to load before starting the main jetty process.  This shouldn't cause any concurrency problems with the Master assigning things, it will just likely cause a little bit of churn in segments loading and unloading.

(1) is something I'd like to do anyway, but it requires a bit of thought around how to do it in a backwards compatible manner.  It seems like (2) could be relatively simple and provide immediate relief though.

Is it a big enough deal to do (2) before (1) can be completed, or can you wait for (1) (O(months) probably, if we are implementing it)

It can wait, it was just Fangjin being very surprised and asking for a ticket. I am sort of used to it.

just fyi: 0.4.28 is causing me more ZK issues than it's solving so far.

We think we may be hitting:

https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CURATOR-24

I'm bumping Druid's Curator version to 2.0.2, something our other internal
services use.

Hrm, that's strange indeed.  You are running redundant realtime nodes right?

I'm thinking that it might be discrepancies in the load rate between the real-time nodes rather than discrepancies between the brokers.

It would be interesting to know if it happens if there is only one realtime node running.  It's probably a lot more practical to do the test the other way around though.  Can you add another nagios check that issues the same query to the same broker twice and see if it gets a different answer?  If it does, then it would be because the broker is picking a different realtime node to respond to the request.

Another option would be to actually query the realtime nodes directly when the discrepancy is happening to see if the discrepancy is happening on them or not.
Not involved, just trying to keep this up to date: There is a pull request now: https://github.com/metamx/druid/pull/158

I thought it might be related to realtime nodes too, hence I set stop = (Date.today - 1).to_time

I.e. no realtime node is queried at all.

But even involving realtime, as long as the interval's end is outside the rt's windowPeriod, there should never be a possibility for two concurrent requests to different brokers to report different numbers, right?
Actually, I wouldn't mind if druid just reports on it's own metrics, as we already use https://github.com/zenops/ganymed
Thanks sixtus. I forgot to link pull request #158 to this bug.
What version is this problem on? I know this was a problem for some earlier versions but I thought it was fixed.
There are some endpoints on the broker that can be used for exploratory purposes (what datasources are available, the dimensions and metrics of each datasource, etc).

Hrm, yeah, it looks like if we just update the twitter4j dependency to 3.0 it'll start working again.  Can you try that out?
We'll probably need to update the tutorial links as well.

I don't think just updating to twitter4j 3.0 is going to work. Twitter no longer accepts basic-auth to access it's stream. You need to have an application only token: https://dev.twitter.com/docs/auth/application-only-auth

I have updated to twitter4j 3.0.3 in this pull request. It is step 1 to fixing the problem, but did not itself fix the problem.  We have to ask the user to go here https://twitter.com/oauth_clients/new and register a new app. This gives them 4 key values they enter into twitter4j.properties like so:

debug=true
oauth.consumerKey=*********************
oauth.consumerSecret=******************************************
oauth.accessToken=**************************************************
oauth.accessTokenSecret=******************************************

Then I think it should 'just work.'  Testing now. The shell scripts need reworking.

See pull request 164: https://github.com/metamx/druid/pull/164

Just generally, I thinkg Sixtus has a point about being able to cherry-pick fixes.  We haven't been too good about that stuff until now, but we should definitely try to get better about it.

We will need you to agree to one of the CLAs as they exist in the current repository? Our CLAs are based on the Apache CLA.

If you are operating as an individual, you can just agree to the Individual CLA, you can simply reply with a comment stating, "I agree to the DruidIndividualCLA as it exists in the master branch of http://www.github.com/metamx/druid on _date_".

If the corporate CLA is the proper CLA for your work, then you will need to first ensure that your corporation has executed the Corporate CLA and you should also add a statement that "I represent that, as _my title_, I have sufficient authority to contribute this contribution under the CLA entered into by _my organization_."

I think the abstractions at play here are a little weird.  Thinking it through, the simplest form of this thing could just be something that checks the InputStream for data on a hasMore() call and does stuff so that getNext() will return the right value.  That is difficult to test, however, so we should have a little bit more abstraction in place to simplify testing.

That said, the abstractions in place right now do not seem to simplify testing.  I think one of the things that makes the tests weird is that the Queue is the shared object, rather than some other abstraction that we have more control over.  Let's step back and re-think how this is done.  If nothing else, the tests should be a lot more straight forward.

One comment on this generally.  I'm toying with trying to use github issue titles as a bullet list of changes for release notes.  For pull requests and issues, can you try to make the title something that would be meaningful on a list of release notes?

Descriptions are also helpful.
It would be really great to have a description on this pull request.  I'm not sure what the goal of the changes was and as such can do little more than just poke at code-level stuff.

I think it will be difficult for pull request titles to have enough information, since they can often be a related collection of changes that are challenging to summarize in one sentence. So I usually try to put that kind of information in commit messages. Github doesn't make it super easy to read them in the context of a pull request, but they're there.

Anyway I c/ped the interesting parts to the pull request description; should I keep doing that or are commit messages okay in the future?
commit messages are good.  I'd still like a summarizing title, I'll try to capture it in the title though.

Druid should always be run with -Duser.timezone=UTC. I agree it should not interpret the Z as local, but there are probably a lot of other codepaths that assume you are running UTC timezone (including our unit tests)

I run all my druid and hadoop daemons in UTC, the hadoop batch config was in UTC.

Just the process spawning the hadoop job was in GMT+2.

Will make the required changes at more appropriate place and re-open a new request.

Thank you for the work on this, but it has gone out of date.  We've recently made a lot of changes to documentation on the master branch, as well as integrated with whirr and things like that, which are the new preferred ways of firing up instances.

This pull request is no longer valid with the changes that were done in master.

Instead I have re-implemented the changes.  You can get them on the new branch master by setting `druid.monitoring.monitors=[\"io.druid.server.metrics.DruidSysMonitor\"]` 

It will pick the directories that are used for storage of segments to monitor.

All of this rackspace stuff is cool!

The code in its current form can no longer be merged and it will be a lot of work to merge it, so I'd recommend actually waiting a bit longer.  We have made a lot of changes to simplify how to add modules to Druid.  All of the Rackspace stuff will now be able to exist as an external module that gets added at runtime.  Once we get that documented, I'd recommend setting this up as that type of module instead (then you don't have to worry about my questions about the dependencies and stuff ;)).

I'm going to leave this open for a bit longer yet.  When I feel like we have the docs in a position that they can be used to create an extension module, I'll let you know by commenting on this issue.
Have we tested this by running a job on a cluster somewhere?
